text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.7.6, Custody and Storage of Seized Assets.
Subsection 9.7.6.2.2 paragraphs (4) and (5) are updated to remove references to the outdated Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (EOAF) Directive.
Subsection 9.7.6.3(1) is updated to change EOAF to Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF). All subsequent references to EOAF is changed to TEOAF.

Subsection 9.7.6.7.3(4) is updated to indicate that a Form 181, Inventory of Seized Vehicles, Vessel or Aircraft, must be completed and provided to the seized property contractor when transferring custody of a conveyance to the seized property contractor.

Subsection 9.7.6.7.3 paragraphs (8), (11) & (12) are updated to reflect that the seized property contractor no longer provides remaining copies of Forms 9572, 9573 or 181 to the Asset Forfeiture Contractor (AFC) or other designated CI contact on site.
Subsection 9.7.6.11.1(2) is updated to remove reference to US Customs and Border Patrol.
Subsection 9.7.6.14(3) is updated to add “Treasury” to Suspense Account. All subsequent references to Suspense Account is changed to “Treasury Suspense Account”.
Subsection 9.7.6.15.2 is re-named Interagency Payments and Collections Deposits/Transfers.
revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes are made throughout the section, which did result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This IRM supersedes IRM 9.7.6 dated August 11, 2008.

) In a civil forfeiture action, property subject to forfeiture is generally taken into custody pursuant to a seizure warrant, or a warrant of arrest in rem in a civil judicial forfeiture action where the property was not previously seized. In a criminal forfeiture action, property subject to forfeiture may be seized to a criminal seizure warrant, or upon entry of a preliminary order of (

) Upon execution of a seizure warrant, the seizing agent will give the person from whom or from whose premises the property was taken, a copy of the seizure warrant and a receipt for the property taken, or leave the copy and receipt at the place from which the property was taken. a. An inventory shall be made in the presence of the person from whose possession or premises the property was taken, if he/she is present, or the presence of at least one credible person other than the seizing and shall be verified by the seizing agent. (
) The return of a seizure warrant to a Federal magistrate shall be made and shall be accompanied by a written inventory of any property taken. (

) The US Attorney’s office should prepare the warrant of arrest in rem to which property will formally be brought within the control of the court. The warrant should set forth the date of the filing of the forfeiture action and notify the recipient of the requirement that a claim be filed within
days an answer within
days thereafter. It should also command the Treasury agent to arrest the property. (

) Pre-arrest planning is critical to the successful forfeiture of properties. ingly, Treasury law enforcement agencies shall ensure to the greatest possible, that all aspects of pre-arrest analysis are undertaken and fully discussed with the Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA). Activities but are not limited to, identity of all persons with an interest in the property, equity, liens, mortgages, outstanding taxes, appraisals, hazard or toxic waste on property, title reports, IRS tax liens, estimated property management estimated disposal costs, live stock, historically significant properties, occupants, tenants, inspections, inventory, writs of entry, contents and nances, need for security-new locks, alarm systems, anticipation that or resistance will be encountered in executing the warrant, etc.
Note: The seized property contractor: may perform all of the services available to Treasury law enforcement agencies for pre-seizure activities (e.g., apprais-

Asset Seizure and als, inventory, photographing, title and lien searches, etc.). The contractor not authorized to conduct the “arresting” of property(ies). The “arresting” shall be conducted by the Treasury law enforcement agency. (

) Execution of Process: The Treasury agent arrests the property by serving the possessor with the warrant of arrest in rem and a copy of the complaint by attaching a copy of the documentation to the property. Service on other fied parties may be served by sending the same documentation to them via certified, return receipt mail. Whether the Treasury agent will have actual custody depends on a number of factors governed by case law in the judicial circuit. The AUSA must be consulted in the decision as to whether to take custody of the property. The general rules are as follows: a. Tangible Property and Real Estate: If possible, the Treasury agent must take actual custody of tangible property. When real estate is the subject of the forfeiture action, the Treasury agent is to take constructive possession by affixing a copy of warrant of arrest in rem to a conspicuous place on the property and serving a copy of the complaint and process on the person in or on his/her agent, see Treasury Directive

- Post and Walk in Light the Supreme Court Decision in United States v. James Daniel Good Real Property for additional guidance. The execution of an arrest in rem does not provide for entrance into tures or otherwise onto properties without a writ of entry or a right of The executing officers may enter upon the property to “post” the and warrant, but may not otherwise venture upon or into the property. investigating officers should discuss fully the merits and needs of a writ of entry or right of entry with the appropriate AUSA prior to the warrant of arrest in rem. If a district court magistrate or judge a writ of entry may be authorized to conduct an inventory and inspection of a dwelling, or some other pertinent activity. A writ of entry does not authorize a search for contraband or other evidence of criminal activity. The court may provide for a right of entry, which is contained in the warrant in rem. Whether a right of entry or a writ of entry is provided, the specific allowable activities for which the entry is granted shall be ated in the order. b. Intangible Property: If intangible property is the subject of the forfeiture action, the Treasury agent executes process by leaving a copy of the complaint and warrant arrest in rem with the obligor or by accepting payment to the court of the amount owed (to the extent of the amount claimed with interest costs). (
) Unless otherwise instructed by the responsible AUSA, the return of service of the warrant shall be made to the AUSA within
days of the execution of the warrant of arrest in rem on the Department of the Treasury Process Receipt and Return form (see Exhibit

). Note: The US Attorney’s office is required to prepare all legal notices regarding property subject to forfeiture by virtue of a warrant of arrest in rem. Since Treasury agency is responsible for the disposition of the asset, it is in Trea- sury’s best interest to determine whether or not the notice requirements been met to avoid disposition problems associated with unknown which may lead to title transfer problems. ) Execution of Process: The Treasury agent arrests the property by serving the possessor with the warrant of arrest in rem and a copy of the complaint by attaching a copy of the documentation to the property. Service on other identi- fied parties may be served by sending the same documentation to them via certified, return receipt mail. Whether the Treasury agent will have actual custody depends on a number of factors governed by case law in the judicial circuit. The AUSA must be consulted in the decision as to whether to take custody of the property. The general rules are as follows:

a. Tangible Property and Real Estate: If possible, the Treasury agent must take actual custody of tangible property. When real estate is the subject of the forfeiture action, the Treasury agent is to take constructive possession by affixing a copy of the warrant of arrest in rem to a conspicuous place on the property and serving a copy of the complaint and process on the person in possession or on his/her agent, see Treasury Directive

- Post and Walk in Light of the Supreme Court Decision in United States v. James Daniel Good Real Property for additional guidance. The execution of an arrest in rem does not provide for entrance into struc- tures or otherwise onto properties without a writ of entry or a right of The executing officers may enter upon the property to “post” the complaint and warrant, but may not otherwise venture upon or into the property. The investigating officers should discuss fully the merits and needs of requiring a writ of entry or right of entry with the appropriate AUSA prior to securing the warrant of arrest in rem. If a district court magistrate or judge concurs, a writ of entry may be authorized to conduct an inventory and inspection of a dwelling, or some other pertinent activity. A writ of entry does not authorize a search for contraband or other evidence of criminal activity. The court may provide for a right of entry, which is contained in the warrant in rem. Whether a right of entry or a writ of entry is provided, the specific allowable activities for which the entry is granted shall be enumer- ated in the order. b. Intangible Property: If intangible property is the subject of the forfeiture action, the Treasury agent executes process by leaving a copy of the complaint and warrant of arrest in rem with the obligor or by accepting payment to the court registry of the amount owed (to the extent of the amount claimed with interest and costs). , Criminal Forfeiture, of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure (Fed. R. Crim. P.) authorizes the seizure of specific property subject to of ture upon entry of a preliminary order of forfeiture. The seizing agent will the person from whom, or from whose premises, the property was taken a copy of the preliminary order of forfeiture, or will leave the copy at the place from which the property was taken. (

) Property under seizure and pending forfeiture shall not be used for any including official use, until such time as the final decree or court order of Under ture is issued - exceptions must be granted by Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF) (see TEOAF Directive Number

, Use of Property Under Seizure). a. Absent the final decree or court order of forfeiture of property under seizure, the United States does not have title to the property. b. Any use of property under seizure and pending forfeiture raises issues liability and creates the appearance of impropriety. (
) All property seized for forfeiture pursuant to
USC §

, except described below, will be transferred to the custody of the seized property of tractor for storage. Pursuant (

) The seized property contractor will take custody of all types of seized except currency and/or monetary instruments, controlled substances (drugs/ narcotics, firearms, Class A and B explosives), and those instances when CI determines that storing the property in another location will be in the best interest. (

) The custody of firearms will not be transferred to the seized property tor. However, upon request, the seized property contractor will provide storage space for firearms. The seized property contractor will maintain istrative custody only (see subsection
, Types of Custody). (
) In addition to the types of property listed above, the seized property will not take custody of property seized for forfeiture pursuant to: a. Title
b. property seized and held as evidence c. abandoned property (

) In order to minimize storage and management costs where seized property (primarily vehicles) has been identified at the time of seizure for official use equitable sharing, the requesting agency should generally be asked to serve as a substitute custodian of the property pending forfeiture. Note: Any use of the seized property, including official use, is prohibited by ment of the Treasury until such time as the forfeiture is completed and the equitable sharing transfer is concluded (see TEOAF Directive Number

Asset Seizure and (

) There also may be situations, such as where at the request of the US Attor- ney’s Office or when adhering to policy of a particular judicial district, CI may choose to manage or dispose of seized property. (

) When seized computer equipment is subject to forfeiture and is found to contain stored data which may be needed for evidentiary purposes, it should remain in the custody of a Computer Investigative Specialist (CIS) until the criminal investigation is completed. (
) There are two separate seized property management contracts, one for personal property and another for real property. Property (

) The Statement of Work (SOW) is the part of a Federal contract that clearly Contracts completely describes the contractor’s work requirements. Excerpts taken from the seized property management services SOW, and its appendices, can be found in this IRM (

). The manual follows closely the format of the SOW, which should be referred to as needed for additional or more detailed tion. The SOW is periodically updated to reflect the most current The Asset Forfeiture Coordinator (AFC) who is trained and certified as a field Contracting Officer’s Technical Representative will maintain a current copy of the SOW. (
) The seized property management contracts provide for services throughout

United States and the District of Columbia, as well as Puerto Rico, all US Property territories and international seizures of real property. The real property Operations tor will provide pre-seizure services when requested. (

) The AFC is the local CI representative authorized to communicate with and task the seized property contractor to perform stated seized property with ment services. All arrangements for the transfer of seized property to the Seized Property property contractor must be arranged by the AFC. The AFC should be aware of and/or approve any contact between the seized property contractor and asset forfeiture support services contractor or any other CI contact. (
) The Warrants and Forfeitures Section will communicate and deal directly with the seized property contractor. (
) The seized property contractor is required to be available to provide stated seized property management services
hours a day,
days a year. The of the Seized seized property contractor will provide telephone numbers to the AFC to use Contractor reach its offices
hours a day, including nights, weekends and holidays. (
) The seized property contractor will keep the AFC informed on how to contact appropriate representatives for off hours pick-up of vehicles, vessels, aircraft, etc. (

) A seized property contractor operated facility (COF) is a facility located in a high volume area workload area which has been designated to store, Operated and dispose of seized property. It may also function as a sales center. (
) The seized property contractor will be responsive to AFC requests to have seized property placed in appropriate storage facilities. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Based on frequent changes in workload, the seized property contractor will locate, evaluate and solicit subcontractors and vendors on a continuous and to supplement the seized property contractor’s capabilities to manage and store property. (

) The seized property contractor is required to adhere to established subcon- tracting guidelines and ensure, on a continuing basis, that all property management service subcontractors and vendors maintain insurance to protect the value of the seized property in accordance with the seized property contract. (
) The seized property contractor will take custody of all seized property, at/or the vicinity of the place of seizure, or at any other location designated by Property (
) The AFC will make any decisions related to the management of any seized forfeited property which is in the seized property contractor’s custody as outlined throughout the SOW. (
) A Disposition Order (see Exhibit
) is used to instruct or task the property contractor to perform stated seized property management Orders An AFC is the only authorized CI contact to sign disposition orders. (

) Disposition orders may be sent to the seized property contractor by (fax) or e-mail; however, the original order must be sent to the contractor. original document may not be required where the seized property allows a statement to be included in the disposition order instructing the property contractor to use the faxed disposition order or e-mailed order as the original. (
) The original disposition order will be signed by the seized property upon completion of any property management services, and returned to the AFC. (

) In the event of a pending seizure, the AFC will notify the seized property tractor as far in advance as possible and will prepare a disposition order of Seized consignment order requesting the pick-up of any seized property. (
) The seized property contractor will respond to a request for transfer of from the AFC within the time period specified in the SOW unless another and time is mutually agreed upon. (

) Seized property will be transferred to the seized property contractor at a nated site or site of mutual agreement. The seized property contractor will and Transfer of inspect and accept custody of property associated with each consignment. Property (
) The seized property contractor will conduct a joint inventory of seized with the AFC or designated CI contact at the time of transfer. (

) Accessories, equipment, and spare parts required for the operation and/or maintenance of the seized property are normally included in the seizure of property. Criminal Investigation should remove all other contents such as personal effects for return to the owner before the seized property assumes custody of the seized property.

) Any movement of seized property from its current physical storage location must be approved by the AFC. The seized property contractor will provide AFC with the Form
, which shows the new location of the seized The seized property contractor, or its designated agent, may contact the to confirm details of the proposed transfer. (

) At the time of the receipt and/or transfer of the seized property, it is the re- sponsibility of the seized property contractor to document the condition of of seized property in writing, videos, and/or photographs. of Seized (
) The AFC, or other designated CI contact on site, will also document the condition of the seized property in writing and may photograph or the property. (
) The seized property contractor will arrange for the safe, secure, and cost- effective transportation of seized property from point of acceptance to an of Seized approved storage site. (

) While the common method of transfer is for the seized property agent/vendor/subcontractor to physically assume custody at the location nated by the AFC, alternate methods may also be agreed upon. For seized property which has been designated for transfer to the seized contractor and can be packaged and shipped via US Mail, United Postal Service, or other responsible delivery service, can be so handled when the seized property contractor and the AFC have determined this procedure to the most cost-effective. (
) The seized property contractor will perform necessary emergency repairs facilitate movement and storage of seized property in accordance with the threshold levels established in the SOW. (

) There are four types of custody for property: a. Regular Custody: The seized property contractor will take physical of Custody sion of property, provide secure storage for property, perform maintenance on property, control access to property, and dispose of property as instructed by the AFC. b. Treasury Agency Custody: Criminal Investigation retains physical of property. c. Administrative Custody: The seized property contractor will provide secured space for sensitive property. Criminal Investigation strictly access to this space. d. Custody Pending Inventory: When directed by CI, the seized property tractor will take custody of certain property without conducting an until CI arranges for a joint inventory at a later date. This must be mented on the Form
) All seized property must be assigned a value upon seizure. The terms “appraised value” and “fair market value” have different meanings in the context of dealing with the seized property contractor.

Any movement of seized property from its current physical storage location must be approved by the AFC. The seized property contractor will provide the AFC with the Form 9573, which shows the new location of the seized property. The seized property contractor, or its designated agent, may contact the AFC to confirm details of the proposed transfer.

) The appraised value (APV) of seized property is the responsibility of CI. AFC, or other designated CI contact on site, will enter the APV for each item on the Form
The seized property contractor will notify the AFC within the time period specified in the SOW when an APV was not the Form
) In situations where a third-party appraisal is required, the AFC may assistance of the seized property contractor in obtaining third-party The third-party appraisal becomes the APV. (

) The following types of seized property may require third-party appraisals: a. conveyances for which there are no established retail value such as an antique b. high-value or specialty jewelry items c. precious metals, stones, and gems d. rare or valuable coins e. objects of art f. antiques or artifacts g. any other unusual, unique, or special items (
) Fair market value (FMV) is defined as the value of property or a given market at which both buyers and sellers are willing to do (

) The seized property contractor will establish a FMV for seized within the time period specified in the SOW after the property has been ferred to the seized property contractor. The seized property contractor will establish a FMV for seized general property at the time it is designated for sale. (

) The seized property contractor will determine the FMV of conveyances by using wholesale value publications such as: a. National Automotive Dealers Association (NADA) Official Use Car b. Aircraft Bluebook Price Digest c. NADA Large Boat Appraisal Guide d. NADA Small Boat Appraisal Guide (

) The seized property contractor will also use past sales experience, local merchants, trade catalogs, publications, manufacturers or other persons knowledge, and/or the internet to establish the FMV of seized property. (
) The seized property contractor will adjust the FMV of seized conveyances annually or immediately prior to the sale of the property, as is necessary. (
) The facilities and methods of storage utilized by the seized property including those necessary for vehicles, vessels, aircraft, and general vary according to need.
9.7 Asset Seizure and Forfeiture
Fair market value (FMV) is defined as the value of property or merchandise in a given market at which both buyers and sellers are willing to do business.
The seized property contractor will adjust the FMV of seized conveyances annually or immediately prior to the sale of the property, as is necessary.
Storage of Seized Assets

) The seized property contractor can acquire storage facilities through lease, subcontract, purchase order, or other contractual arrangements. The seized property contractor is able to provide temporary, short, or long term storage throughout the
United States and the District of Columbia, as well as Rico and all US territories. (

) The seized property contractor may use all established Contractor Operated Facilities (COF). The current COF leases contain a provision that all lease agreements can be assigned to a successor prime contractor. The seized property contractor will subcontract for the most cost effective facilities that meet stated requirements at all times. If the subcontractors and/or vendors outside a particular field office location, the seized property contractor will obtain the AFC’s approval before using the vendor. Any property stored of the field office location will be clearly identified as such by the seized property contractor. (
) Government or municipally owned facilities (Federal, state, or local) may be available at little or no cost, especially for conducting sales. (

) Seized property will be stored by the seized property contractor in the most cost-effective method available to preclude any deterioration of the property that the physical condition of the property is maintained as it was at the acceptance. Methods of storage will range from open storage to highly facilities, depending upon the type of seized property to be stored. (
) Depending on geographical area and giving consideration to climate, and other variable factors such as value, rarity, etc., some vehicles may require inside storage. (

) Water is the primary cause for the deterioration of certain vessels. Salt significantly increases the deterioration. For vessels in short or long term storage that are stored in water, the maintenance and deterioration costs be more than the cost of removing the vessel from the water and storing vessel on land. The seized property contractor will determine the most cost- effective type of storage on a case-by-case basis. The decision will be on vessel size, appraised value, and condition at the time of seizure. (

) Humidity in the air is a major cause for the deterioration of aircraft. The storage of aircraft near large bodies of salt water significantly increases this deterioration. The short and long term storage of aircraft in non-humid ments minimizes deterioration, and is preferred when costs of transportation such sites are not prohibitive. (
) The seized property contractor will accept livestock, fowl, perishables, and other unusual items of general property that may be seized in violation of enforced by the Department of the Treasury. (
) The following subsections cover the real property management services the real property contract.

For vessels in short or long term storage that are stored in water, the maintenance and deterioration costs be more than the cost of removing the vessel from the water and storing the
Asset Seizure and (

) The seized property contractor will provide assistance and property ment services for seized real property for both residential and commercial properties such as dwellings, buildings, farms, businesses, and associated physical items and mechanical systems. Such seizures are non-routine, handled on a case-by-case basis, and may involve assistance on the day of seizure, post-seizure management, and disposition. Pre-seizure planning is essential when seizing real properties. (

) The seized property contractor will provide, or obtain from licensed als when requested by the AFC, the following specific services: a. pre-seizure analysis b. initial services upon transfer of real property to the seized property con- tractor c. appraisal (internet appraisals for initial cost-benefit analyses, appraisals from a licensed real estate appraiser at a subsequent time determined the AFC) d. title search and report (licensed) e. security f. maintenance, improvements, and cost to remediate lead-based paint other hazard substance contamination as tasked by the AFC g. operation of commercial businesses h. management and rental i. disposition/sale of real property (
) Pre-seizure services available from the seized property contractor are in IRM
, Pre-Seizure Planning. (

) The seized property contractor is not authorized to conduct or perform the arresting or post and walk of real or personal property. The arresting must conducted by CI or other Treasury law enforcement agency. (

) Upon receipt of a Disposition Order from the AFC which requires the to make entry into the property, the seized property contractor will contact or other designated CI contact regarding arrangements for the location, and time of the scheduled entry with CI presence. (

) The AFC or designated CI contact on site will have in their possession the court order that authorized entry (writ of entry) to the property and the ments of the court. The seized property contractor will not enter the unless accompanied by a representative from CI. The seized property tor will provide specific services requested via Disposition Order issued by AFC, and accompanied by the court order. These services may include but not limited to: a. obtaining a title search and report b. photographing and video filming c. inventory of the property and contents d. appraisal of the property e. monitoring and oversight of the posted property by drive-by f. evaluating and/or monitoring operating businesses by performing such functions as conducting stock inventories and auditing operation and financial records g. other SOW services directed by the court through CI

) Headquarters concurrence is required before real property and businesses are seized by CI and transferred to the seized property contractor. For specific cedures to obtain HQ approval to seize real property and businesses, see
, Pre-Seizure Planning. (

) The seized property contractor will be provided the following documents from CI before transfer of custody of a real property seizure: a. a copy of the warrant or court order which states the seized property con- tractor is authorized to enter the property for management and disposal purposes b. writ of entry, if applicable (

) Upon transfer of custody of a real property seizure to the seized property con- tractor, the AFC will specify, in writing, the type and extent of initial property management services desired. The seized property contractor may be tasked by the AFC to perform services that may include, but are not limited to, the following: a. appraisal b. evaluation
identification of residential properties and/or building structures for lead- based paint

by the AFC to perform services that may include, but are not limited to, the following: a. appraisal b. evaluation c. statement of condition d. estimate of rental value e. estimate of maintenance costs f. environmental condition and lead-based paint inspection g. security requirements h. identification of any unusual hazards or circumstances (

) Unless otherwise specified at the time of transfer, the seized property tor will videotape the property and contents with both interior and exterior views. The seized property contractor will take photographs of damaged property and will submit photographs along with the estimate for repairs to AFC. (

) For pre-seizure planning and cost benefit analyses, the seized property tractor will conduct internet appraisals to determine the approximate value real property. When a full appraisal is required, the seized property will use licensed real estate appraisers. These appraisals must be with the published standards of the American Institute of Real Estate ers and the Society of Real Estate Appraisers. (
) The seized property contractor will use a licensed real estate title company attorney to provide a title search and report on specified parcels of real property. (
) Security requirements, alarm systems, and security guards, where will be coordinated with and authorized by the AFC.

Asset Seizure and (

) Unless enforcement requirements mandate otherwise, before the transfer of custody of real property that includes ongoing commercial businesses or other enterprises, the seized property contractor will perform a written analysis and evaluation to determine the cost and feasibility of continuing to operate the business. The seized property contractor will also determine any or other problems that could make seizure inadvisable or cost prohibitive. (
) Occupancy issues are a concern in civil judicial and criminal forfeiture actions involving real property. and (
) Except as provided in
USC §

, real property that is the subject of a civil Real judicial forfeiture action shall not be seized or custody transferred to the seized property contractor before entry of an order of forfeiture. The owner or occupants of the real property shall not be evicted from, or otherwise deprived of the use and enjoyment of, real property that is the subject of a pending for- feiture action. The filing of a lis pendens and the execution of a writ of entry the purpose of conducting an inspection and inventory of the property shall not be considered a seizure. (
) If real property is occupied and not vacated upon entry of an order of forfei- ture, CI may either enter into a Post Forfeiture Occupancy Agreement (Exhibit

) or consult with the AUSA responsible for the forfeiture regarding eviction. During the time that the occupant(s) have possession of the property, the occupant(s) will maintain insurance on the dwelling(s) and show proof of insurance to the AFC upon request. The occupant(s) and the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) will sign the agreement. (

) Real property subject to forfeiture in a criminal forfeiture action will not be seized or custody transferred to the seized property contractor, absent unusual circumstances, until the court enters a preliminary order of forfeiture. After the preliminary order of forfeiture is entered, and prior to a final order of forfeiture in a criminal forfeiture action, occupants of real property may be permitted to remain on the property pending the forfeiture. If the real property is occupied, CI will enter into an Occupancy Agreement (see Exhibit
). Both the occupant(s) and the SAC will sign this agreement. The occupancy agreement in Exhibit
was developed by and issued as an attachment with TEOAF Directive Number

, Occupancy Agreements, and includes various that address Department of the Treasury concerns. The language of this document is intended to take the agreement out of the realm of state landlord/ tenant law and establishes that the agreement is a license, rather than a This enhances the government’s position in evicting occupants if necessary. During the time the occupant(s) reside in the property, the occupant(s) will maintain insurance on the dwellings and show proof of insurance to the AFC upon request. (

) Upon entry of an order of forfeiture in a civil judicial forfeiture action or final order of forfeiture in a criminal action, and assurance that no stay of the order has been issued as part of an appeal, the AFC will deliver, by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested, a letter to the occupant(s) of forfeited real property (see Exhibit

, Eviction Letter). This letter will advise the occupant(s) that the property has been forfeited, that the occupant and all personal property must be vacated by a specific date, and that any personal property left on the premises will be considered abandoned property, without value, and will be disposed of according to law. ) If the occupant refuses to vacate the premises, the AFC and/or agent will consult with the AUSA responsible for the forfeiture in the event eviction is necessary. (
) The seized property contractor will maintain vacant and occupied real and obtain suitable tenants and manage rental properties as provided in and Rental written instructions from the AFC. (

) The seized property contractor will perform all maintenance, ordinary and replacements necessary to preserve the property in its condition at the time of acceptance in accordance with the threshold levels in the SOW. seized property contractor is authorized to perform emergency repairs in dance with the threshold levels in the SOW. (
) The seized property contractor will ensure that all repairs or alterations all local building codes, zoning ordinances, and other ordinances as the jurisdiction where the property is located. (

) The seized property contractor will obtain rental tenants subject to terms periods of time specified by the AFC. The seized property contractor will ensure that lease provisions and rental practices conform to those in use in the community unless otherwise specified by the AFC. (
) The seized property contractor will ensure that parties renting the premises agree to conditions of tenancy, including prearranging visits by CI and month-to-month rental conditions. (
) The seized property contractor will prepare the premises for rent by and taking other necessary property maintenance actions. (
) The seized property contractor will maintain strict accountability, by seizing agency seizure number and line item number, of all seized property in its custody. (

) The seized property contractor strictly controls access to property, access only to authorized seized property contractor representatives, pre- Seized designated CI contacts, and those individuals who present a Disposition signed by an AFC. Pre-designated CI contact, authorized in writing to be granted unlimited access to seized property (no Disposition Order and seized property contractor personnel are required to provide before access to property is granted. Court orders must be accompanied Disposition Orders. The seized property contractor will contact the AFC for structions when individuals without a Disposition Order request access to property. Authorized vendor and subcontractor personnel will accompany visiting party at all times to assure security of property. (

) The seized property contractor, subcontractors, and/or vendors will not any information about seized property to anyone until the disposition order remission or other disposition is issued. All requests for information will be referred to the affected AFC.

Asset Seizure and (

) The seized property contractor will maintain and preserve seized property necessary to ensure that it retains its value, operating ability, and overall condition from the time of acceptance until disposition. Preservation but is not limited to: a. protection from heat, cold, humidity, water damage, weather, insects, rodents (rats, mice), dirt, dust, and contamination b. property lubrication, painting, and other upkeep dictated by the value type of property (
) To fulfill maintenance requirements, the seized property contractor will cost-effective maintenance procedures. (

) The seized property contractor will perform initial maintenance that will of checking fluid levels, tire inflation, cleaning of interior and exterior, and routine initial maintenance for the preliminary protection of the conveyance pending preparation and implementation of a more comprehensive tion and maintenance plan. The initial maintenance cost will not exceed the amount specified in the SOW without the consent of the AFC. (

) The seized property contractor will prepare a preservation and plan for each consigned conveyance within the time frame specified in the SOW. This plan will include repairs needed, as well as preventive mainte- nance, showing material and labor costs, and frequency of maintenance. (
) The seized property contractor will implement periodic maintenance as specified in the SOW or directed by the AFC. (

) The seized property contractor will perform necessary initial maintenance seized property such as rugs, furs, perishables, etc. in order to preserve Property in the same condition as at the time of acceptance. These types of seized property may require follow-up maintenance to be implemented as the SOW or directed by the AFC. (

) The seized property contractor is authorized to perform whatever repairs necessary to ensure that seized property (primarily conveyances) is Refurbishment, rily transported and stored in accordance with the threshold levels in the and (

) For property to be sold, the seized property contractor will give to and make recommendations to the AFC for approval regarding the or functional repair, refurbishment, rehabilitation, or modification of forfeited property when such action would enhance its value over and above the accomplish any such action. Any expenditure will not exceed the amount specified in the SOW without the approval of the Contracting Officer. (

) Risk management is defined as a method of management that identifying, assessing, and mitigating potential problems in the receipt, Management management, and disposition of seized and forfeited property. (

) Risk management is an important element of the seized property contract. Successfully implementing an effective risk management process is to reduce or eliminate losses that can result from lack of control over risk events such as loss, damage, or theft of seized and forfeited property.

) The seized property contractor shall take specific measures to: a. avoid loss or damage to seized and forfeited property under its actual constructive control b. avoid fraud, waste, and abuse c. evaluate facilities and their security aspects d. evaluate subcontractors’ suitability, performance, and insurance e. promptly report actual adverse incidents and potential adverse f. control hazardous material g. promote risk awareness
) The seized property contractor will provide the AFC and the Director, (
) with copies of all litigation documents and court orders immediately upon Litigation and Court receipt, but no later than specified in the SOW. Orders (

) The purpose of this requirement is to keep the government fully informed enable it to respond in a timely manner to potential notice, litigation, and issues. Timely notification or lack thereof may be used as a measure of seized property contractor’s performance.
) The seized property contractor is responsible for detecting, identifying, (

) managing hazardous materials according to any Federal, state, and local Control of Hazard codes, ordinances, and regulations that apply to environmental quality Materials standards in each community where seized property is maintained or destroyed. (

) The seized property contractor will inform the AFC of an adverse incident, (

) which includes any loss, destruction, and/or damage to seized property. Adverse Incidents seized property contractor is required to submit a written final report of gation of an adverse incident to the Director, Warrants and Forfeiture.
) The security, budgetary, and accounting problems caused by retention of (

) amounts of cash has caused great concern within CI, the Department of Storage of Seized Treasury, and Congress, and raises both financial management and Currency, Financial control issues. Accounts, and Financial Note: The term “cash” includes currency, personal and commercial checks, Instruments cashier’s checks, bank checks, traveler’s checks, money orders, etc. (
) The timely deposit of cash assets is important to the effective the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. The TEOAF Directive Number
, Seized Management Policy, establishes Department of the Treasury policy on the management of seized cash. (

) The Treasury Suspense Account is the holding account that is the CBP in its capacity as Treasury Executive Agent for the Treasury Fund for seized cash pending resolution of forfeiture cases. The Treasury Suspense Account is located at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The seized property contractor shall take specific measures to:
Note: The term “cash” includes currency, personal and commercial checks, cashier’s checks, bank checks, traveler’s checks, money orders, etc.
The timely deposit of cash assets is important to the effective management of the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. The TEOAF Directive Number

, Seized Cash Management Policy, establishes Department of the Treasury policy on the management of seized cash. The Treasury Suspense Account is the holding account that is administered by the CBP in its capacity as Treasury Executive Agent for the Treasury Forfeiture Fund for seized cash pending resolution of forfeiture cases. The Treasury Suspense Account is located at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Asset Seizure and (
) Currency and financial instruments seized for Title
violations must not deposited into the Treasury Suspense Account or the Treasury Forfeiture (

) Criminal Investigation policy mandates that domestic and foreign currency seized for forfeiture, except where it is to be used as evidence or held as “collectible asset” must be expeditiously counted, processed, and into the Treasury Suspense Account within
days of seizure. The use of deposit boxes or other secure methods of temporarily storing seized is acceptable when necessary. (
) Refer to IRM
, Evidence Seizures, for the required procedures to the appropriate approvals to hold seized currency as evidence. (

) Seized currency will be transported with appropriate security measures to ensure safe transportation to the physical site of deposit. The CI contact remain at the site until the currency is recounted, if necessary, by the facility and a proper receipt is provided for the deposit. (

) Proceeds from seized financial accounts, including checking, savings, market, mutual funds, and brokerage accounts, will be deposited into the Accounts Treasury Suspense Account unless they are “frozen”. (
) Because the value of financial instruments can be lost or diminished if procedures are not followed, TEOAF issued Directive Number

, Seizures Instruments Financial Instruments. The following financial instruments seized for are to be handled in accordance with the procedures in Directive Number a. postal money orders b. personal checks c. cashier’s check d. certificate of deposit e. traveler’s checks f. stocks and bonds g. US savings bonds h. airline tickets (
) The TEOAF Directive Number

includes instructions for several methods available for the deposit of cash into the Treasury Suspense Account. for the Note: The deposit of seized funds at Federal Reserve Banks is no longer one of the methods available for the deposit of cash into the Treasury Funds to the Account. Suspense (
) Fed Wire or Electronic Funds Transfers can be accomplished by using a mercial bank to wire transfer seized funds into the Treasury Suspense Deposits Account. (

) Most banks require an established account with the bank from which wire transfers will be drawn. Since there is latitude on the part of commercial in their handling of wire transfers, it may be necessary for CI contact to develop a business relationship with a bank in their geographical area and process wire transfers in accordance with their protocols and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R
Currency and financial instruments seized for Title 26 violations must not be deposited into the Treasury Suspense Account or the Treasury Forfeiture Fund.
The TEOAF Directive Number 4 includes instructions for several methods available for the deposit of cash into the Treasury Suspense Account.
Note: The deposit of seized funds at Federal Reserve Banks is no longer one of the methods available for the deposit of cash into the Treasury Suspense

Most banks require an established account with the bank from which wire transfers will be drawn. and Storage of Seized Assets
page (

) Banks also charge a fee for the wire transfer. This fee cannot be deducted from the seized funds being transferred. Each field office will implement dures to provide for the payment of the wire transfer fee incurred. (

) Some banks may allow the wire transfer of funds without the sender having account with the bank. The field office may wish to negotiate an agreement have such a bank process wire transfers without establishing an account. (

) There is no standardized format or form in the banking industry for the pro- cessing of wire transfers. The information generally required to send wire transfers to the Treasury Suspense Account is contained in TEOAF Number
and Exhibit
) Interagency Payments and Collections (IPAC) is an electronic transfer that uses the Government On-line Accounting Link System to transfer Payments inter-agency. The TEOAF Directive Number
presents IPAC instructions. (
) Whenever a wire transfer or direct deposit is made into the Treasury Account, a copy of the TEOAF Form #
, Deposit Information Form (see Reporting
), along with the wire transfer or direct deposit receipt should be forwarded to the HQ-W&F mailbox, as soon as it is received. (

) If one of the methods described above cannot be used to deposit/transfer seized funds into the Treasury Suspense Account, the seized funds may be of Seized Funds delivered, in the form of a cashier’s check or other negotiable instrument Executive payable to the Department of the Treasury, to the Warrants and Forfeiture Asset Section for delivery to TEOAF for deposit into the Treasury Suspense (
) The seized funds can be delivered in person or mailed to: IRS-CIInternal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation Warrants & Forfeiture Room
Constitution Ave, NW Washington, DC
) A properly completed Form #
, Deposit Information Form, must be included with the check or other negotiable instrument.

Banks also charge a fee for the wire transfer. This fee cannot be deducted from the seized funds being transferred. Each field office will implement proce- dures to provide for the payment of the wire transfer fee incurred.

Whenever a wire transfer or direct deposit is made into the Treasury Suspense Account, a copy of the TEOAF Form #6, Deposit Information Form (see Exhibit 9.7.6-7), along with the wire transfer or direct deposit receipt should be forwarded to the HQ-W&F mailbox, as soon as it is received.
A properly completed Form #6, Deposit Information Form, must be included with the check or other negotiable instrument.

“This Occupancy Agreement (“Agreement”) is made betweenInternal Revenue Service (“IRS™).

On o+ the United States of America, by and through the IRS, seizedunder authority of a bearing case number yunder the provisions of andauthority of Title » United States Code, Section » & parcel of realproperty (“Property”) Jocated at N » which includes all fixtures andappurtenances thereto, and which is described as follows:

By order dated , the United States District Court for the enteredjudgment in favor of the United States and forfeited the property that is thesubject of this agreement to the United States. This is a final disposition bythe Court.
The undersigned (“Occupant”), , resided on the property when it wasseized and desires to continue to reside there pending final disposition of theforfeited property.

Therefore, it is hereby agreed, upon execution of the Agreement, and incompliance with all the terms and conditions stated herein, that the Occupant maycontinue to occupy the property until directed to vacate by the IRS.

Occupant shall be permitted to occupy the residence located on the propertysubject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement as long as the IRS permifit is understood by the Occupant that this Agreement does not create anyinterest in the land or a tenancy of any kind, but rather this Agreement is
icense by the IRS to occupy this property and is subject to revocation for.violations of the terms and conditions of this Agreement.

The IRS shall have the right to re-enter the property, with or without theconsent of the Occupant, at reasonable times to inspect and/or appraise theproperty, or for any other purpose consistent with this Agreement.
